snippet: If we don’t change the economics of legal education, law schools will graduate streams of economic casualties each year and an enormous barrier to the legal profession will be erected.
abstract: Op-Ed article by law Prof Brian Z Tamanaha contends the economics of legal education are broken, and that the federal loan system and the accreditation standards for law schools imposed by the American Bar Assn are largely to blame; offers suggestions for how to fix the system.
lead_paragraph: If we don’t change the economics of legal education, law schools will graduate streams of economic casualties each year and an enormous barrier to the legal profession will be erected.
